direction.raw_text: ! INT. MASRY & VITITOE, FILE ROOM - DAY Erin is alone, filing as she talks on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long's she been crying like that? ... Well, she's got that tooth coming in -- Ed appears in the door, carrying the box of files.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give her a cold washcloth to suck on -- (sees Ed) I gotta go -- there's a clean one in that bag -- I'll check back in a bit. (hangs up) Sorry.  My kid -- ED Where's Anna?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out to lunch with the girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.  Huh. (beat) Well, look, I got this file I need valued. Real estate thing.  A lady has some property next to a PG&E plant that PG&E wants to buy. I need to know what to ask for it. He plunks the box of files on her desk.  She stares at it, with no idea of how to go about that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.  Okay. He sees her staring at the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do know how to do that, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  I got it.  No problem.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Ed heads out, but pauses before leaving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come you're not at lunch with the girls? You're a girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I'm not the right kind. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, FILE ROOM - NIGHT Erin is at her desk, staring bewildered at the files from the box Ed gave her, which are now spread across her desktop. She sees Anna packing up her things, to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anna?  With this real-estate valuing stuff - - could you remind me, cause I'm a little confused about how exactly we do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Erin, you've been here three weeks.  If you don't know how to do your job by now, I am not about to do it for you. EXT. ERIN'S HOUSE - NIGHT Katie and Matt are running up to the house.  Erin follows, toting Beth under one arm and the box of documents under the other.  She steps on another water bug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ugh. As she wipes the bug guts off the bottom of her shoe:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, neighbor, wanna beer? She spots George on his stoop, with a six-pack beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: C'mon.  I bought 'em for you, to make up for that night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Return 'em.  Maybe you'll get your money back. He gets up and follows her to her house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, why're you giving me such a hard time? I'm just trying to be a good neighbor. Erin turns to him.  The kids are waiting at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had a good neighbor, George.  She was 60 and Mexican and she watched my kids for free.  Something tells me you're not gonna be able to measure up to that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You need help with your kids?  I could probably do that. George reaches out and grabs the box from under her arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not gonna leave my kids with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cause I don't even know you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, and whose fault is that? He's got a point there.  After a beat:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, you got so many friends in this world, you don't have use for one more? INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT George is on the floor with Matt and Katie, playing War. Katie points to the Harley emblem on his leather jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that stand for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's for Harley Davidson.  The best damn motorcycle ever made. Erin comes in from the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if I catch either of you anywhere near one, I'll knock you silly.  Go on to bed, now -- I'll come tuck you in in a minute. They get up ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Night. ... and head into bed.  George starts cleaning up the cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great kids. Erin bends down to help him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  I'm probably ruining them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm never here.  I gotta leave 'em with this weird sitter all afternoon who costs a fortune and smells like chicken fat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was serious before, you know.  If you need someone to keep an eye on them -- after school or something -- I don't have a job now, so I'm around in the afternoons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great.  Another deadbeat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not a deadbeat.  I work when I need to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?  And what do you do the rest of the time, live off your trust fund?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do construction, which pays real good. And I make it last by living cheap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope that's not supposed to impress me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you this hard on everyone who tries to help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's been a while.  Maybe I'm just out of practice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then lemme remind you, the polite thing is to say, thank you, that's a real nice offer, I don't mind taking you up on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why in the hell would you want to watch my kids?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cause I like kids.  I like hanging out with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right. She starts cleaning up the cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do.  I like how they keep it all simple, you know?  They don't get all complicated about life, like grown-ups do.  A bicycle and an ice cream cone -- boom, done, they're happy. Erin thinks about the offer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're around every afternoon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yup.  Usually working on my bike. (she's tempted) No big deal.  If it doesn't work out, you can send 'em back to the chicken fat lady. Tempting.  Erin looks him over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't gonna get you laid, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, we'll just see about that, won't we? INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, ERIN'S BEDROOM - NIGHT The wee hours.  Erin's in a t-shirt, sitting on her mattress on the floor.  The paperwork from the box is now spread all over the floor around her.  She's reading a letter. CLOSE ON THE LETTER It's from PG&E, to Donna and Peter Irving.  We see the phrases, "purchase your house ...", "fair market value ..." CLOSE ON ANOTHER DOCUMENT It's a list of comparable house sales in the area.  Owner, cost; owner, cost.  Every house is in the $65,000 range. From another room, she hears the sound of BETH CRYING.  Still reading the file, Erin gets up and goes into: INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, BETH'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Still reading, Erin gets Beth out of her crib.  Beth quiets. INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, ERIN'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Erin lies down on the mattress and rests Beth on her chest. She sets down the file she was reading and picks up another. CLOSE ON THE FILE It contains a letter from a Dr. Howard Reeves.  The first paragraph contains the phrase "... medical examination of Donna and Peter Irving ..." Toward the end of the letter, there are two columns.  One is headed: "IN RANGE".  The other: "OUT OF RANGE".  Under that head appear the following: "lymphocytes, T-lymphocytes, natural killer cells, T Helpers, T8 suppresser cells". Erin stares at it, confused. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, COFFEE AREA - DAY Erin is talking to Jane, who's pouring herself coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was in this real estate file I'm valuing. And -- see, I know they're the medical records from the people selling the house -- but it talks about things like lymphocytes and T8 suppressers. Erin sees Ed pass behind Jane.  She lowers her voice, so he won't see her asking for help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean, it's not a problem or anything, but
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm just a little unclear on what those things are.  I thought maybe you'd know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do I look like, Erin?  A library? And Jane walks away with her coffee. EXT. UCLA MAIN LIBRARY - DAY Large.  Looming.  Very establishment.  Through the windows, we see Erin at the desk, talking to a LIBRARIAN.  She has the file in her hands.  Over this:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Masry & Vititoe, can I help you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, Rosalind, this is Erin.  Brockovich. From the file room?  I was wondering if you could tell Mr. Masry that I'm following up on that real estate thing out of the office. The librarian gives her directions to somewhere else. EXT. UCLA MEDICAL LIBRARY - DAY Smaller, but still establishment.  Erin's Hyundai pulls into the parking lot. INT. UCLA MEDICAL LIBRARY - DAY Erin is at the reference desk, eating a candy bar while she talks to the LIBRARIAN.  He checks something on the computer. A couple of WHITE-COATED MEDICAL STUDENTS pass her, double- taking.  They don't see many like her around here. INT. UCLA SCIENCE BUILDING, HALLWAY - DAY A long, academic hallway lit by fluorescents.  Erin gets off an elevator and heads down the hall.  She finds a door with a nameplate that reads "Jim Paulsen, Epidemiology" and KNOCKS. The door opens and DR. JIM PAULSEN appears.  He's a classic scientist: unruly hair, thick glasses.  Nothing like Erin has ever shown up at his door.  He reels at the sight of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Paulsen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, I'm Erin Brockovich.  I was just over in the library there, asking a mess of questions about -- I guess they call it epidemiology? -- and the fella there told me to find you, cause you know all about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this a joke?  Did Baxter put you up to this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's Baxter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He did, didn't he? Baxter ! BAXTER, another scientist, leans out of a door down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? Baxter and Erin look at each other.  No recognition, of course.  Paulsen is immediately embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.  Oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one put me up to anything.  I was just hoping I could ask you a couple questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course!  Oh, gosh, of course -- INT. PAULSEN'S OFFICE - DAY Orderly chaos.  Dr. Paulsen, still recovering, has Erin's file in his hands.  Erin is sitting across from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, look, there isn't a ton of information here, but from what there is, I'd say that these two people here -- what are their names?  Shanna and Ashley?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, I guess those are the kids -- PAULSEN They've both got some immune system problem. Can't say what from, whether it's viral or genetic or what, but something's wrong.  And these guys -- Donna and Peter -- ERIN Their parents, I'm pretty sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, from what this stuff says, I'd say they both have some form of cancer. Wow.  That's more serious than Erin was expecting. INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, KITCHEN - DAY CLOSE ON THE FILE on the kitchen counter.  The Irvings' phone number is written on the front.  A PHONE IS RINGING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoa, whoa!  Easy, easy, easy -- WIDEN to see Erin, phone to her ear, grabbing a carton of juice from Matt and Katie, who are fighting over it at the table.  Just as she takes it from them, the phone picks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi!  You've reached the Irvings.  Leave a message and we'll get back to you just as soon as we can.  Bye-bye. BEEP.  Erin thinks a bit, then hangs up and looks at the file.  Scrawled on the cover is the Irvings' address, in Hinkley, California. EXT. L.A. FREEWAY - DAY The beat-up old Hyundai heads east out of L.A.  DISCO MUSIC blares from its speakers. EXT. HINKLEY, CA - DAY This is a dry, desolate part of California.  No downtown, no community.  Just tract after tract of arid farmland, with small, bland, unprotected ranch home cropping up out of the landscape like occasional tombstones. A beat-up old sign on the road reads: "HINKLEY, CA.  POP: " but the  corner where the number would be has broken off. As a gust of wind lifts dust from the fields, Erin turns onto Community Boulevard, the main road that cuts through Hinkley. INT. ERIN'S HYUNDAI - DAY Erin looks around.  The house she's passing has been razed. A heap of lumber and wires in the middle of the property. As she checks the piece of paper with Donna's address, she drives by the PG&E COMPRESSOR STATION, a massive gray structure of pipes, chimneys and ladders, set way back from the road.  Erin passes it without noticing it. She stops at an intersection.  The house on the corner has been boarded up with plywood.  Erin notices it -- depressing -- then turns the corner onto Donna's street. EXT. DONNA IRVING'S HOUSE - DAY A generic ranch home standing all alone in the middle of nothing.  There's a pool out back and a chain link fence hugging the property.  No landscaping.  Dull, but clean.  A few BOTTLES OF SPRING WATER wait by the door. The Hyundai pulls into the driveway and stops.  Erin gets out.  As she heads up to the door, her spike heels sink into the dirt.  She rings the bell.  It has a melody chime. DONNA IRVING opens the door.  She's 35, petite, with a scrappy, high-strung manner.  She's wearing tight jeans, and her dark curls are piled on top of her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi.  Donna Irving?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Erin Brockovich, from Masry & Vititoe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a lawyer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell, no.  I hate lawyers.  I just work for them.  You got a minute? INT. THE IRVINGS' HOUSE, LIVING ROOM - DAY The house is furnished with little money, but lots of care. Erin's on a plaid couch, in a sea of needlepoint pillows. Out back, two GIRLS, ages 9 and 11, are playing in a pool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a real nice place you got here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well it oughta be, with all the work I put into it. She comes out from the kitchen with a tray of iced tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I added air conditioning, put in the pool, made all those pillows by hand ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah?  I should learn to do stuff like that. They make the place feel real homey. Donna corrects the positioning on a couple of pillows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.  I think so too.  That's why I'm being such a stickler on this house price thing.  I don't mean to be a pain in PG&E's backside, especially after all they've done for Hinkley, but I look around here and I think, if they want this place, they're gonna have to pay for it.  And I don't just mean pay for the house; I'd like them to pay me for the trouble of starting over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cause first you gotta move, then there's decorating, and if the windows aren't the same size, you know -- you're making all new curtains.  Honest to God, I don't know if I have the energy.  You know, I've been sick. Me and Peter both have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I'm real glad you brought that up.  I was going through your file here, and I ran into these medical records.  They kinda surprised me -- This would be the perfect opportunity for many to get self- pitying.  But not Donna.  Life's handed her a shitload of lemons, and darned if she hasn't made a shitload of lemonade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.  They're more than a bit unusual. See, two years ago, Pete got Hodgkin's disease.  That's a kind of cancer -- ERIN Yeah, I'm real sorry to hear that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.  It's in remission now, thank the Lord, but you never know.  And then while that's going on, I end up having to have a hysterectomy.  Plus a whole mess of lumps removed from my breasts.  All benign so far, but still, no matter how positive you stay, an operation can still take it out of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll say.  Holy moley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So the whole idea of selling the house -- don't get me wrong, I'd be glad to move to some better place, but if they aren't gonna pay us properly, I just don't see the point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I can see that. (beat) I guess the only thing that confused me is - - not that your medical problems aren't important, but -- how come the files about them are in with all the real estate stuff? Donna tops off their iced teas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you kidding?  With how our lives are, if I start subdividing files, I'll be sunk.  I just kept all PG&E correspondence in one place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, but -- I'm sorry, I don't see why you were corresponding with PG&E about it in the first place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, they paid for the doctor's visit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They did?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bet.  Paid for a check-up for the whole family.  And not like with insurance where you pay, then wait a year to be reimbursed, either.  They just took care of it.  Just like that.  We never even saw a bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wow.  Why would they do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cause of the chromium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The chromium.  Well, that's what kicked this whole thing off. INT. IRVING HOUSE, GARAGE - DAY CLOSE ON A BOX, with "CHROM INFO" scrawled on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: &E came around a few years ago, told us they put chromium in our well by mistake. And since we shouldn't have to drink it if we don't want to, they gave us free spring water and offered to buy our house. WIDEN to see Donna pulling the box down into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's chromium?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a chemical they used over at that compressor station up the road there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, hell, maybe that's why you all have been so sick -- DONNA I thought the same thing, right off the bat. That's why we went to see the doctor.  But hunh-uh.  Turns out one's got nothing to do with the other. She rifles through the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the info they gave us.  You'll see if you look through it, chromium's good for you.  When I saw what they charged for it at the health-food stores, I about fainted. She hands Erin a printed fact sheet.  Erin scans it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seems like an awful big coincidence -- your water being messed with and you being so sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not around here.  This is a rough part of the world.  Hard times, not a lot of money, not a lot of luck. (beat) It's a challenge, staying healthy in a town like this.  Heck, even our dogs up and die. INT. ERIN'S CAR - NIGHT Erin's driving away from Donna's house.  A street lamp throws light on the box of chromium documents in the passenger seat. She gets to an intersection and looks across the street at the massive COMPRESSOR STATION.  Six stories high, lit up like a Christmas tree, with all sizes of PIPES criss-crossing the outside and GIANT COOLING TOWERS sticking up out of it. Far more massive than anything else in town, it looms over the horizon like the Capitol in D.C. or St. Peter's in Rome. Erin takes a long look at the compressor station, then turns onto Community Boulevard and drives away. INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, KITCHEN - DAY Erin is holding Beth, making her a bottle, when she hears NOISES coming from outside.  She follows them. EXT. ERIN'S HOUSE - DAY Erin opens the door to find George attaching bars to her windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What're you doing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better safe than sorry. She shakes her head, amused by his persistence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want some coffee, George? INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, KITCHEN - NIGHT George follows Erin in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gonna put a dead bolt on your front door, too.  This isn't exactly the safest neighborhood in the world, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for reminding me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess we get what we pay for, huh? Erin pours him some coffee, hands it to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think it could make you sick, living in a place like this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean? George settles in, helps himself to sugar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was talking to this lady -- she and her husband both got cancer, and she thinks it's cause they live in a bad neighborhood.  You think that's possible?  That living in a bad neighborhood could give you cancer? George laughs a little at the thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man, I hope not.  You got enough damn problems. But Erin's still mulling it over. EXT. NORTHRIDGE, ERIN'S BLOCK - DAY Erin clips down the block in short-shorts and high-heeled boots.  Up ahead a few of DOWN-ON-THEIR-LUCK MEN are out on a stoop, drinking their breakfast.  Erin approaches them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, y'all -- how you doing today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hangin' in, baby.  How about yourself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm okay, I'm just fine.  I was wondering -- could I maybe ask you a couple questions? She settles down on the stoop with them for a chat. INT. PAULSEN'S OFFICE - DAY Dr. Paulsen and Erin are sitting, talking.  He's thrilled to have her back in his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... and when I realized our area's just as bad as Hinkley, I thought maybe my neighbors are all sick too.  So I went and asked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did? Erin digs a pad of paper out of her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-huh.  Spent the last few days knocking on doors.  And you know what?  They're not. (reads from the pad) I mean, they got problems, but none of this cancer stuff.  And their pets are fine.  So I don't know -- I just can't shake the feeling that it wasn't no multivitamin they put in the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if you're talking about contamination, you're getting out of my area of expertise. Let me give you the name of a toxicologist friend of mine over at USC. Paulsen reaches for a notepad, scrawls on it. INT. UCLA MEDICAL BUILDING, HALLWAY - DAY Paulsen is seeing Erin out of his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gotta say, Erin -- first time I saw you, I did not peg you as the kind to go off and conduct her own epidemiological study.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't go telling anyone.  It'll ruin my reputation. EXT. USC CAMPUS - DAY Erin towers over DAVID FRANKEL as she walks across campus with him.  He's the grittier variety of scientist: Patagonia, Birkenstocks, bushy beard.  He's as dry as dust, and as much as Dr. Paulsen responded to Erin, Frankel barely notices her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of chromium is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's more than one kind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  There's straight-up chromium -- does all kinds of good things for the body. There's chrom 3, which is fairly benign, and then there's chrom 6, hexavalent chromium, which, depending on the amounts, can be very harmful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harmful, like -- how?  What would you get?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With repeated exposure to toxic levels -- God, anything, really -- respiratory disease, liver failure, heart failure, reproductive failure, chronic headaches, bone or organ deterioration -- plus, of course, any type of cancer. He rattles it off coolly.  Just facts.  Erin's stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So that stuff -- it kills people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yeah.  Definitely.  Highly toxic, highly carcinogenic.  Bad, bad stuff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, how do I find out what kind of chromium is up in Hinkley?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you been to the water board?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hunh-uh.  What's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every county has one.  They keep records of anything water-related within their jurisdiction.  You should be able to find something there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: County water board.  All righty, thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck. (beat) Oh -- I wouldn't advertise what you're looking for if I were you ... His line continues over: EXT. LAHOTAN REGIONAL WATER BOARD - DAY Erin's Hyundai pulls up and stops in a cloud of dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Incriminating records have a way of disappearing when people smell trouble. Erin hops out, checks her reflection in the side-view mirror, then heads into the building. INT. LAHOTAN REGIONAL COUNTY WATER BOARD - DAY Drab, government-issue.  ROSS, the bored desk clerk is thumbing his way through ROAD & TRACK.  Just as he stops to stare at a motor oil ad in which a buxom blonde is straddling the hood of a car, the huge door opens and Erin enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whew!  God damn , that's a heavy door. Ross looks up.  It's like the girl from the ad walked right off the page.  He jumps up, to help her with the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, hey -- lemme give you a hand there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you very much.  Aren't you a gentleman?  Mr. ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ross.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ross.  Real pleased to meet you.  I'm Erin. She smiles.  He can't believe his luck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Erin.  Cool.  What can I do for you, Erin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, believe it or not, I am on the prowl for some water records.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You come to the right place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess I did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just tell me what you want to look at and I'll be glad to dig 'em out for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I knew.  It's for my boss.  He's fighting his water bill, and he wants me to find all manner of bills from all kinds of places.  The easiest thing would probably be if I just squeezed back there with you and poked around myself.  Would that be okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heck, yeah.  Come on back.  Just gonna need you to sign in here -- He hands her a pen.  He reads over her shoulder as she signs her name -- Erin Pattee Brockovich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pattee?  That your middle name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nope.  Maiden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not anymore. She smiles and winks at him, then goes around the counter with him and looks at the stacks and stacks of files.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well.  Here goes nothing. She heads down an aisle, reading the spines of the files. They're all town names -- Barstow, Victorville, Oro Grande, Helendale -- in no particular order.  Finally, Erin spots one that says Hinkley.  She pulls it down. IN THE FILE are pages and pages of Xeroxed memoranda, letters, charts, graphs, handwritten notes.  All shoved in willy-nilly. INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, MAIN ROOM - DAY George is watching a football game on TV.  He's just put TV dinners on the floor in front of the Matt and Katie. MATT Our mom gives us sandwiches on Fridays. GEORGE That's a sandwich. KATIE No, it's not! GEORGE Sure it is.  Here, I'll show you. He picks up Matt's chicken, tears it in two ... GEORGE Most people think a sandwich's gotta have bread on the outside.  Not true.  Chicken is a perfectly good outside for a sandwich. ... then places the broccoli neatly between the halves. GEORGE See? Katie and Matthew look at it, then up at George, and smile. This guy just might be all right, after all. EXT. WATER BOARD - NIGHT It's gotten dark.  Erin's Hyundai's still there. INT. WATER BOARD - NIGHT Erin is on the floor, her legs stretched out in front of her. She has a bunch of files open and spread across the floor. The one in her hand has caught her attention. INSERT ON THE PAPER It's a memo titled "CLEAN-UP AND ABATEMENT ORDER" from the water board to PG&E.  Erin is concentrating hard on it, reading laboriously to herself. ERIN (O.S.) "... On December 7, 1987, the discharger notified the regional board and the San Bernardino County Environmental Health Services of the discovery of 0.58 ppm of hexavalent chromium in an on-site ground water monitoring well ..." (beat) ... hexavalent ... INT. MASRY & VITITOE, RECEPTION - DAY CLOSE ON A XEROX OF THE ABATEMENT ORDER.  WIDEN to see it is on top of a stack of papers that Erin is carrying as she enters the office.  She has an efficient air about her -- a sense of purpose. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, FILE ROOM - DAY Erin swoops in, ready to work, only to find her desk cleared off.  She turns to Anna, who's already hard at work. ERIN Where's my stuff? Anna looks up. ANNA Where've you been?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the fuck did you do with my stuff? ANNA Don't use language with me -- But Erin's out the door before Anna can finish her sentence. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, JANE'S OFFICE - DAY JANE is at her desk.  Erin barrels in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone stole my stuff. JANE Nice to see you, Erin.  We've missed you. ERIN I had photos of my kids, plus a mug -- Jane reaches under her desk for a box, looks through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: toothbrush, toothpaste, and a pair of hose.  Here. ERIN What's going on? JANE There may be jobs where you can disappear for days at a time, but this isn't one of them.  Here, if you don't do the work, you don't get to stay. She hands her the box.  Erin doesn't take it. ERIN I've been working.  Shit, that's all I've been doing.  Ask Mr. Masry.  He knows. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY Ed's at his desk, dialing the phone when Erin barrels in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said to fire me? He sets down the receiver. ED Erin, you've been gone for a week. ERIN I left a message.  I've been dealing with that real estate thing.  I was gonna write up a whole damn report and -- ED That's not how we work here.  You don't just leave a message and take off. Jane follows her in, still carrying the box of stuff. ERIN What am I supposed to do, check in every two seconds? JANE Yes.  It's called accountability. ERIN I am not talking to you, bitch. JANE Excuse me ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, enough -- (beat) Now, look, Erin -- this incident aside, I don't think this is the right place for you. So what I'm gonna do is make a few calls on your behalf.  Find you something else, okay? ERIN Don't bother. She turns to Jane, takes her box, and heads out. ED Come on, I'm trying to help here. ERIN Bullshit.  You're trying to feel less guilty about firing someone with three kids to feed.  Fuck if I'll help you do that. And she leaves. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, OUTSIDE ED'S OFFICE - DAY As Erin heads for the door, pleased glances fly from secretary to secretary.  Erin reaches the door, but can't open it with the box in her arms.  She turns to the room. ERIN I don't suppose any one of you cunts could open the fucking door for me. EXT. ERIN'S HOUSE - DAY Erin's Hyundai rumbles to a stop in front of the house.  Erin shoves open the creaky, reluctant door, lifts her box of stuff off the seat, and gets out. As she walks around the car and toward the house, she runs into the MAILMAN.  He hands her a packet of mail. MAILMAN Here ya go, Miz Brockovich. Erin looks at the top of the stack.  It's the electric bill. INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, MAIN ROOM - DAY Erin enters, puts down the box and stares at the mail. Bills, bills, and more bills.  As she throws them on the table, she sees George coming out of the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here? GEORGE Fixing a leak under your sink. She heads into the kitchen, weary and irritated. ERIN I didn't ask you to do that.  Damn it, George, I don't ask you to do things like that. INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, KITCHEN - DAY Erin enters, sees all the cleaning stuff from under the sink is spread around the kitchen floor.  A tool box lies open. ERIN Great. GEORGE I'm gonna clean it up. Erin gets down on her knees and starts putting things away. GEORGE Relax, Erin, I'll do it -- I'm not -- Before he can finish, a huge WATER BUG runs onto Erin's hand. ERIN Ugh -- Jesus -- She jumps and brushes it off. GEORGE Yeah -- you had a whole family of those things hanging out back there. She takes off her shoe and smacks at the bug, missing it. ERIN Damn it -- The bug skitters away from her, along the floorboard.  Erin chases it, smacking at it repeatedly, missing it every time. GEORGE Don't worry about it, I'll get it later. But Erin keeps after it, corralling all her frustrations into killing that one bug. ERIN Come here, you little motherfucker -- The bug crawls up onto the table, zipping behind the salt, the pepper, the napkin holder.  Erin keeps after it, BANGING the table harder and harder with each SMACK of her shoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, whoa -- relax -- The salt and pepper skid off the table.  The napkins fly from their holder.  Just as Erin's about to nail the bug, it slips into a crack in the wall and disappears.  Erin hurls her shoe at the crack.  It SMASHES into the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... God damn it. She looks around at her for-shit kitchen and starts to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of person lives like this?  Huh? What kind of person lets her kids run around in a house crawling with bugs the size of housecats?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a simple thing.  Everybody gets them. All we gotta do is call an exterminator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't call an exterminator.  I can't afford one.  God, I can't even afford my phone . (beat) I got fired.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?  But you been working so hard -- ERIN Doesn't matter.  Doesn't make one bit of difference. (then, fragile) Oh God, George, how'd this happen to me? How'd I end up so ... so nothing ? George picks a napkin up off the floor, hands it to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not nothing, Erin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm sure as hell not what I thought I was gonna be.  I was supposed to have one of those great lives, with everything all laid- out and perfect.  I mean, hell -- I was Miss Wichita, for God's sakes.  Did I tell you that?  You live next door to a real live beauty queen. (wipes her nose) I still got the tiara.  I kept it cause I thought it meant something.  I thought it meant I was gonna do something great with my life.  I thought it proved I was gonna grow up to be someone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are someone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No I'm not.  Look at me.  I'm not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're someone to me. (beat) You're someone real special to me. He takes a step toward her and kneels in front of her, very close.  He takes her shoe from her hand and puts it back on her foot.  Then he takes her hands in his and kisses them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm no good, George.  I make people miserable. But he kisses her anyway.  And for the first time in so long, she feels like something other than a failure.  He pulls her into him, and she lets herself be pulled. INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, ERIN'S BEDROOM - DAY Erin and George are in bed, naked, curled around each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man.  Even your earlobes are beautiful. He kisses one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be too nice to me, okay?  It makes me nervous. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY Ed is at his desk.  The PHONE RINGS.  And RINGS.  And RINGS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brenda! (no answer)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ! As Erin stands there staring at the wall, her breath starts to come heavily -- those deep breaths that precede tears. She slowly slides down into a chair, defeat overcoming her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ! Nothing.  Ed growls in frustration, then gets the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, Ed Masry here ... She doesn't work here anymore.  Who's this? INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, KITCHEN - DAY CLOSE ON THE TABLE, where Beth is bobbing in her baby chair. On one side of her is a heap of bills with "PAST DUE" and "PLEASE REMIT" stamped on them.  On the other, the well- thumbed CLASSIFIED SECTION, with circles and X's all over it. The DOORBELL rings.  Erin swoops in and picks up Beth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, baby.  Maybe that's Ed McMahon. INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, FRONT DOOR - DAY Erin carries Beth over to the front door, spies through the peephole, and sees Ed standing there.  She opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got an interesting call this afternoon. It was from a Dr. Frankel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yeah?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wanted you to know the legal limit for hexavalent chromium, is .05 parts per million.  And that at the rate you mentioned, .58, it could be responsible for the cancers in that family you asked about. The Irvings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that was nice of him.  Isn't it funny how some people go out of their way to help people and others just give 'em the ax?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'm sorry.  You were gone.  I just assumed you were off having fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, why in the hell would you assume that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.  Maybe cause you look like someone who has a lot of fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, are you ever a shitty judge of people. Ed takes a beat, copping to the charge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what's the story on this thing?  This cancer stuff?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wanna know, you gotta hire me back.  I got a lot of bills to pay. He glares at her.  Realizes he has no choice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. INT. ERIN'S HOUSE, LIVING ROOM - LATER Erin has let Ed in.  They're sitting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, PG&E told her about the chromium?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They told her something, but it can't have been too specific, cause I talked to her, and she sure didn't think her water was bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what made you think it was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't take a genius to look at those medical records and think something's wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What medical records?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ones in the box of files. (off Ed's blank look) The box of files?  The one from your office?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't see any medical records in there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, you musta really fine-tooth-combed it then, huh? (to herself) And you fired me .  Jesus. Ed thinks for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That document you found, the one that says it was the bad chromium -- you didn't happen to make a copy did you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Course I did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lemme see it, will you? Before getting it for him, she looks at him, weighs her odds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want a raise.  And benefits.  Including dental.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Erin, this is not the way I do business, this extortion nonsense. Erin doesn't budge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.  A 5% raise, and -- ERIN Ten. (off his look) There's a lot of other places I could work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A ten percent raise and benefits.  But that's it.  I'm drawing the line. She goes to her box of stuff from the office and digs out the document for him.  He scans it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the only thing you found?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So far.  But that place is a pig sty.  I wouldn't be surprised if there's more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Find out. EXT. 10 FREEWAY - DAY Erin's Hyundai zips along the freeway.  "Funky Town" is blaring from the tinny stereo.  Over it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate this music. INT. HYUNDAI - DAY Erin's driving.  Matthew's in the front seat.  Katie and Beth (in a car seat) are in the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no way a son of mine hates Funky Town.  It's impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I hate it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate it too.  I hate this trip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, come on, where's your sense of adventure?  We're going someplace you never been before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm gonna hate it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me too. She glances at them, frowns a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I'm realizing for the first time?  You kids are a couple of downers.  I mean, you are the real thing -- a couple of honest-to-God depresso-types. (small smile) Who in the heck raised you, anyway?  Some kind of moron? Katie smiles a little.  She likes this side of her mom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  A real moron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some kind of half-wit, no-good, big-haired, bimbo, I bet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank God we got you away from her, huh? By now they're all smiling.  Funky Town plays on. EXT. PG&E COMPRESSOR STATION - DAY The Hyundai is parked at the entrance to the station, by a row of dead trees.  Erin is standing beside a sign that says "Private Property.  No Trespassing", taking pictures of the massive structure in the distance.  Matthew, Katie, and Beth are drawing in the dirt with sticks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay out of the road.  I'll be right back. She wanders up the drive, onto PG&E property, moving around the plant, taking pictures of it from every possible angle. As she wanders over a big, flat, dry field to the side of the plant, she glances over her shoulder to check on her kids and notices the trail she made in the dirt has a greenish hue. She looks at the dirt right her feet.  Kicks the ground. Below the surface, the dirt turns from brown to green.  Erin notes this, then looks back at her kids playing in the dirt. Worry comes over her face.  She heads back to them. EXT. HINKLEY MART - DAY The kids are waiting at the car.  Erin comes out of the store with a bottle of water and uses it to rinse off their hands. EXT. WATER BOARD - DAY The sound of a BABY CRYING.  The Hyundai's parked in front.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm hungry. INT. WATER BOARD - DAY Erin is at the Xerox machine, copying a file while she tries to calm Beth.  There's a stack of files on the nearby table. Matthew and Katie are flopping around on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll go eat in a minute.  Settle down. Whining, fussing.  Ross goes over to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what, Erin?  I got nothing but time here.  Why don't you let me do that for you, and you can get your kids some dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ross -- you are an absolute angel. She hands Ross the STACK OF DOCUMENTS. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, BRENDA'S DESK - DAY Ed comes in in the morning, and without pausing, hands Brenda a copy of the STACK OF DOCUMENTS, with a Post-it on the top.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fax these to this number, okay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of 'em?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of them. He continues into his office and closes the door. CLOSE ON THE FAX MACHINE LED Brenda types in the number.  The recipient's I.D. comes up on the LED: PG&E CLAIMS DEPT. INT. IRVING HOUSE, LIVING ROOM - DAY Another copy of those DOCUMENTS, now in Donna's hands.  She's on her couch with Erin, reading them.  Outside, Donna's two daughters are playing in the pool.  She reads the last page and looks up at Erin, bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An on-site monitoring well?  That means -- ERIN It was right up on the PG&E property over there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you say this stuff, this hexavalent chromium -- it's poisonous?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well -- then it's gotta be a different than what's in our water, cause ours is okay. The guys from PG&E told me.  They sat right in the kitchen and said it was fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.  But the toxicologist I been talking to?  He gave me a list of problems that can come from hexavalent chromium exposure. And everything you all have is on that list. Donna resists this idea hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  Hunh-uh, see, that's not what the doctor said.  He said one's got absolutely nothing to do with the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, but -- didn't you say he was paid by
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: &E? Donna sits quietly, trying to make sense of this.  The only sound is the LAUGHING and SPLASHING from the pool out back. Then, gradually, Donna realizes what it is she's hearing -- her kids playing in toxic water.  She jumps up ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !  SHANNA! ... and runs out to the pool.  Erin follows her. EXT. DONNA'S HOUSE - DAY From the door, Erin watches Donna run to the edge of the pool in a frantic response to this news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: !  BOTH OF YOU, OUT OF THE POOL, RIGHT NOW !
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How come?
direction.name: direction

DONNA CAUSE I SAID SO, THAT'S WHY, NOW GET OUT

direction.raw_text: !  NOW!!! Erin watches compassionately as Donna flails to get her kids out of the contaminated water. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, ED'S OFFICE - DAY It's morning.  Ed is checking the lie of his tie in his reflection in the window.  Erin is on his couch, high-heeled legs stretched out in front of her. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, BRENDA'S DESK - CONTINUOUS Jane is delivering paychecks.  When Brenda gets to her desk, Jane tips her head toward Ed's office, as if to say, check it out.  Brenda peers in and sees Erin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's she doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hired her back.  With a raise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?? Why ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, let's see.  It's not cause she's smart, and it's not cause she's professional.  That leaves ... Brenda's stunned.  Takes a beat.  Makes assumptions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And dumb old me thought working hard and being loyal was the way to get ahead. INT. ED'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Ed is still checking his reflection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm telling you, the minute Brenda sent the fax -- I'm talking the second she pressed that send button -- PG&E claims department is on the phone to me, scheduling a meeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you think we got 'em scared?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It sure as hell sounded like they were sitting up and taking notice. Brenda pops her head in, ignores Erin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: David Baum from PG&E is at reception. Erin feels the chill Brenda's sending her way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice to see you again, too, Brenda. Brenda leaves without acknowledging Erin. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, MAIN ROOM - DAY Ed and Erin come out and see DAVID BAUM waiting at reception. Forget law school, this kid looks like he's just out of twelfth grade.  Not a hair on his chin.  His suit and shoes look brand new.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not to question your judgment or anything, Mr. Masry, but -- that doesn't exactly look like sitting up and taking notice to me. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY Ed and Erin are seated across the table from Baum. To say this kid lacks authority is a gross understatement.  He doesn't talk; he squeaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... in the interest of putting this whole thing to rest, PG&E is willing to offer the Irvings 250,000 dollars for their home. Ed laughs a little in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In terms of land value out in Hinkley, Mr. Masry, we feel it's a more than fair price.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about in terms of medical expenses?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: doesn't come close to what this family's gonna have to spend on doctors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand they've had a bad run of luck, health-wise, and they have my sympathies. But that's not PG&E's fault.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're kidding, right? (Baum doesn't answer) Look at these readings for Christ's sake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: &E's own technicians documented toxic levels of hexavalent chromium in those test wells, on numerous occasions. Ed shoves them across the table.  Baum doesn't look at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything the Irvings have had is a proven reaction to exposure to hexavalent chromium. They've had ... He stalls a moment.  Erin jumps in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: breast cysts, uterine cancer, Hodgkin's disease, immune deficiencies, asthma, chronic nosebleeds. Despite their persuasiveness, Baum parrots what is obviously the party line:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A million things could have caused those problems.  Poor diet, bad genes, irresponsible lifestyle.  Our offer is final and more than fair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute -- I thought we were negotiating here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is all I'm authorized to offer. Ed looks across at this pissant little kid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Christ. (he stands, to leave) I will present your offer to my clients.  I doubt they'll accept it. As Ed starts out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Masry, before you go off on some crusade, you might want to remember who it is you're dealing with here.  PG&E is a 28- billion dollar corporation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.  I'll keep it in mind. And Ed leaves the conference room.  Erin follows him out. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, MAIN ROOM - DAY Erin follows Ed as he stomps back to his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least they made an offer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That wasn't an offer.  A million would've been an offer.  When they send the God damn mail clerk down to jerk me off, waste my time, it's a fuck you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't get why they'd do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because they can.  You heard that kid -- they have 28 billion dollars at their disposal.  They can afford to waste all the time in the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you can't?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, you think I'm made of money? Behind them, Baum steps out of the conference room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, you know where I can get a cab?  My plane leaves Burbank in forty-five minutes. Ed turns and looks at him.  He gets a tiny smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell you what, why don't you go on over to reception, tell them I said Mario should take you to the airport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, excellent.  Thanks. Baum heads out to the reception area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Masry, Mario gets lost going to the bathroom.  They'll be driving around the valley for hours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Isn't that a shame? She watches him go into his office, impressed.  Big smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I'll be God damned. INT. MASRY & VITITOE, OUTSIDE ED'S OFFICE - NIGHT End of the day.  Most everyone has left.  Erin is at her new work space near Ed's office.  She's poring over a fat file of documents.  ROSALIND wanders by with her coat on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been reading for hours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a slow reader, on account of the fact that I look at the word "dog" and see "god".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, just so long as you see Him. Rosalind turns on Erin's desk lamp and heads out. Outside the big glass office doors, Rosalind stops to talk to a lost-looking COUPLE IN THEIR MID-30's.  These are MANDY and TOM BROWN.  He's a security guard uniform, with an envelope under his arm.  Rosalind points to Erin.  The Browns enter the office and approach her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, are you Erin Brockovich?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Who are you?
direction.name: direction
